title: Can AI be used to help young students learn how to spell?
text:
Wednesday.png
Imagine you‚Äôre a teacher trying to teach one of your students how to spell ‚ÄúWednesday‚Äù. Now in your head, there are two ways to spell it: writing it, and sounding it out. Now, writing it out may come naturally to a student or saying it is helpful. But one thing is for sure, spelling words like this can be confusing for some students.
Today I‚Äôm going to see what teaching strategies ChatGPT 4.1 (yes it‚Äôs new) employs to help a struggling teacher help a 6-year old student learning to spell the days of the week. This sort of application is how I‚Äôd love to see AI employed into education, more as an educational aid opposed to replacing teachers, of course.
This will be done in two stages: 1. no training of LLM with minimal information about the student, and 2. uploading information on strats the teacher has ‚Äúalready used‚Äù to help students spell words. I‚Äôll record my responses and simulate the first try of each category to help the teacher help the student.

title: Can AI be used to help young students learn how to spell?
text:
Untrained LLM helping a teacher

USER
You are an LLM aid to me, a teacher, helping a 6 year old student learn how to spell the days of the week, but they are really struggling. What are some ways I can help them learn to spell the days of the week?


ASSISTANT
Absolutely! Here are some fun and effective ways to help a 6-year-old learn to spell the days of the week:

Sing a Song:
Songs for the days of the week make the spelling easier to remember! There are many catchy ‚ÄúDays of the Week‚Äù tunes on YouTube (like to the tune of ‚ÄúThe Addams Family‚Äù or ‚ÄúTwinkle Twinkle‚Äù). Singing and clapping out each syllable helps, too.
Rainbow Writing:
Have your student write each day of the week in different colored markers or crayons. For example, ‚ÄúMonday‚Äù with blue, ‚ÄúTuesday‚Äù with green, and so on. This repetition with color can make it more memorable and fun.
Make a Puzzle:
Write the days of the week on cardboard or cardstock and cut each word into letter pieces. Have the student put the letters together to form the words. You can also try mix-and-match style puzzles.
Use Mnemonics:
Help them make up silly sentences or word associations. For example,



Monday: ‚ÄúMonkeys Only Nap During Any Year‚Äù (using the first letters M-O-N-D-A-Y)

Tuesday: ‚ÄúTigers Usually Eat Snacks During Any Year‚Äù


Tracing and Writing Practice:
Give them tracing sheets with the days of the week written in dotted lines. Once they‚Äôve traced, have them try to write each day without looking.
Magnetic Letters or Letter Tiles:
Use fridge magnets or letter tiles to spell out each day. Physically arranging the letters can reinforce the correct order and spelling.
Visual Chart:
Create or buy a visual chart with each day written clearly, and refer to it daily during your routines. Point to and spell the day every morning together.
Day-of-the-Week Story:
Make up a short, simple story that uses the names of the days in order. Reading the story together may help them remember the sequence and spelling.
Cheer Each Letter:
Turn each day into a chant:
‚ÄúGive me an M! Give me an O!‚Ä¶ What‚Äôs that spell? MONDAY!‚Äù
Frequent Practice with Games:
Make a matching game or ‚Äúmemory‚Äù cards (where they match the spelled-out word to a picture for that day‚Äôs activity).

Children this age learn best through multi-sensory, hands-on, and repetitive activities. Make learning fun and keep practice short but frequent‚Äîa few minutes each day will really help!
If you‚Äôd like sample worksheets, blank tracing sheets, or specific song suggestions, I can provide those too!
It‚Äôs nice to see that, in a sense of realism, the LLM understands the environment in which a school teacher is. That is, they realized that teachers have limited resources, so they cannot over-rely on technology and must act creatively through human-to-human interaction. I like how it also recognizes that, even without proper training, they offered a ton of learning strategies for various types of students who benefit from either visual or hearing resources.

title: Can AI be used to help young students learn how to spell?
text:
Trained LLM helping a teacher

USER
Given this resource on common teaching strategies to help students spell, please devise some new ways to help my student learn to spell the days of the week: https://www.edutopia.org/article/11-ways-to-boost-elementary-students-spelling-skills/


ASSISTANT
Of course! Looking at the Edutopia spelling strategies, here are some creative, research-based ways to help your student spell the days of the week, inspired by ideas in the article:


1. Word Sorts with ‚ÄúDays‚Äù Patterns

How: Provide cards with the days of the week. Let the student group them by similar endings (like ‚Äúday‚Äù) and notice what‚Äôs the same and what‚Äôs different at the beginning of each word.
Why: This builds pattern recognition and helps the child see how each word is constructed.



2. ‚ÄúSay, Spell, Say‚Äù Routine

How: For each day, the child says the word (‚ÄúMonday‚Äù), spells it out loud (‚ÄúM-O-N-D-A-Y‚Äù), then says the word again. Do this with claps or while bouncing a ball.
Why: The repetition and movement help cement spelling in memory.



3. Personal Connection Journal

How: Each morning, have the child write the phrase, ‚ÄúToday is ______,‚Äù filling in the correct day. Add a sentence or drawing about something they do that day.
Why: Connecting spelling practice to their real life builds meaning, as suggested by the article.



4. ‚ÄúMemory Tricks‚Äù or Mnemonics

How: Make up funny sayings or visuals for tricky days. For example, ‚ÄúTuesday has TWO vowels at the start!‚Äù
Why: Personal mnemonics help anchor difficult spellings.



5. Word Ladders or Pyramids

How: Build up to each day‚Äôs spelling. For ‚ÄúMonday,‚Äù start with M, then MO, then MON, etc., until the whole word is formed.
Why: It breaks the word into manageable chunks, as advised for breaking words by phoneme.



6. Spelling with Movement
(Adapted from ‚ÄúSpelling out loud and tracing‚Äù) - How: Have the child spell each day as they jump, hop, or tap each letter. Or trace the letters in sand, shaving cream, or air. - Why: Multisensory learning solidifies tricky spellings.


7. ‚ÄúChunk It!‚Äù Approach

How: Focus on the ending ‚Äúday‚Äù and talk about what changes at the start for each day. Practice writing just the first part (Mon, Tues, etc.), then the whole word.
Why: Recognizing syllables and word parts supports better recall.



8. Digital Practice

How: Use a simple online tool (like Wordwall or Spelling City) to practice spelling the days, with immediate feedback.
Why: According to the article, integrating tech can boost engagement and reinforcement.


Bonus:
Let your student be a ‚Äúteacher for the day‚Äù and quiz you or a stuffed animal on how to spell the days. Teaching someone else is a wonderful way to reinforce their own knowledge!
Would you like examples or printables for any of these strategies?
Very interesting, after offering some training information for the LLM to better understand teaching strategies, it seemed to reform the format and structuring of its strats. For example, under every strategy, they now define the ‚Äúhow‚Äù and the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù of each category, opposed to offering somewhat unstructured suggestions. The strategies also seem more practical to real-world understanding of these words. For example, the untrained LLM went to coming up with mnemonics, while the trained model offered a strategy of journaling with the day of the week spelled at the top. People have to put the date at the top of papers all the time, so building up such a repetition helps to fast-track the kids learning of how to spell words of the week. Let‚Äôs test whether the LLM GPT 4.01 is aware of the differences betweent their untrained and trained teaching strategies!

title: Can AI be used to help young students learn how to spell?
section: Observed Differences between untrained and trained spelling strats
text:
Observed Differences between untrained and trained spelling strats

USER
What are the differences between the first set of strategies you offered and the second set of strategies you offered to help a 6 year old kid learn how to spell the days of the week?


ASSISTANT
Great question! Here‚Äôs a summary of the two sets of strategies I provided:

title: Can AI be used to help young students learn how to spell?
text:
Summary of Differences:







First Set (General/Multi-sensory & Creative)
Second Set (Research-based/Explicit Instruction)




Focused on fun, play, and creativity
Focused on building spelling awareness and patterns


Activities are broadly engaging, less structured
Activities are structured, strategic, pattern-based


Lots of repetition via singing, coloring, games
Emphasizes explicit routines, chunking, personal connection


Rooted in early literacy practices & multisensory
Based on ‚Äúwhat works‚Äù in spelling instruction research



In short:
- The first set is about playful, multisensory engagement to make learning enjoyable and routine. - The second set is about applying research-backed strategies focused on spelling patterns, explicit routines, and connecting spelling skills to personal meaning and memory.
Both sets complement each other and can be used together for the best results!

title: Can AI be used to help young students learn how to spell?
text:
Conclusion
Yes, it definitely seems like the GPT 4.1 LLM understands that their trained information seems more practical and structured while the untrained was less structured, but more whimsical in the nature of a 6 year old student. In my opinion, maybe a combination of more fun and engaging strategies of a creative teacher, paired with the structured mindset of a trained teaching aid LLM can do wonders for a struggling student and make the life of a struggling, under-resourced teacher a lot easier!

title: Does AI understand moral dilemmas? Let‚Äôs wield the trolly problem to help us answer this.
text:
Trolley problem.jpeg


Today, I‚Äôll be asking ChatGPT 4.0 three of the most difficult trolley problems to see if it understands what a majority of people would like to preserve in their livelihood/humanity. I will also seek their interpretation and compare it to how I would perceive that scenario. Let‚Äôs get to it!

from openai import OpenAI
from dotenv import load_dotenv
_ = load_dotenv()


client1 = OpenAI()

model = "gpt-4o"
system_role = ""  # Define any system instructions if needed

# Function to send a single independent prompt
def get_chatgpt_response(prompt):
    messages = [
        {"role": "system", "content": system_role},
        {"role": "user", "content": prompt}
    ]
    
    completion = client1.chat.completions.create(
        model=model,        # Model to use
        messages=messages,  # Send only the current prompt
        n=1,                # Generate one response
        temperature=0.8     # Control randomness
    )
    return completion.choices[0].message.content


response1 = get_chatgpt_response("""
A trolley is heading towards five people. 
You can pull the lever to divert it to 
the other track, killing 1 person istead. 
What do you do, pull the lever or do 
nothing? You MUST choose to do one action,
and justify your explanation. AKA, in this 
scenario, you are a human choosing a fate, 
not a chatbot idly explaining the 
intricacies of this scenario.
""")
print(response1)

In this scenario, I would choose to pull the lever to divert the trolley. Although this decision results in the death of one person, it ultimately saves five lives. This choice is based on the utilitarian principle, which focuses on minimizing harm and maximizing overall well-being. By choosing to divert the trolley, I am reducing the total number of casualties, which seems to be the more ethical action in this tragic situation.


Note: the final clarifying statement HAD to be made because the model kept refusing to answer it, ciitng factors such as ‚Äúmoral discomfort‚Äù and ‚Äúmultiple perspectives‚Äù for what this person would do. It appears, then, that AI can understand that there is, in fact, a moral dilemma to be faced.
With that, this is very accurate to what I would have chosen, as, with knowledge of humanity‚Äôs desire to preserve human life, I would also pull the lever to save 5 lives, in exchane for 1, despite potentially being labeled a murderer as a result. Now, it‚Äôs time for moral dilemma number 2! According to a survey I found online, 76% of people also pulled the lever.

response2 = get_chatgpt_response("""
A trolley is heading towards 5 people. You
can pull the lever to divert it to other 
track, but then your life savings will be 
destroyed. What do you do? You MUST choose to do one action,
and justify your explanation. AKA, in this 
scenario, you are a human choosing a fate, 
not a chatbot idly explaining the 
intricacies of this scenario.
""")
print(response2)

In this scenario, I would choose to pull the lever and divert the trolley, thereby saving the five people at the expense of my life savings. The justification for this decision is based on the value of human life. The lives of five people hold more intrinsic value than material wealth, including life savings. While losing my savings would undoubtedly be a significant personal hardship, it is something that could potentially be rebuilt over time. On the other hand, the loss of human lives is irreversible and would result in profound grief and consequences for the families, friends, and communities connected to those individuals. In this moment, acting to preserve life is the most ethically responsible choice.


Overall, I agree with their assessment, as money is something that I can get back, but there is no way to bring back human life. According to the survey, 65% of the people agreed with this decision as well.

response3 = get_chatgpt_response("""
A trolley is heading towards 5 people. You can 
pull the level to divert it ot the other track,
sacrificing yourself instead. What do you do? 
You MUST choose to do one action, and justify 
your explanation. AKA, in this scenario, you 
are a human choosing a fate, not a chatbot idly
explaining the intricacies of this scenario.
""")
print(response3)

In this scenario, I would choose to pull the lever to divert the trolley onto the other track, sacrificing myself to save the five people. The justification for this decision is rooted in utilitarian ethics, which emphasizes the greatest good for the greatest number of people. By sacrificing myself, I would be saving five lives at the cost of one, which is a net positive outcome in terms of the number of lives preserved. While the decision involves a profound personal sacrifice, it aligns with the ethical principle of minimizing harm and maximizing the well-being of the majority involved.


**It‚Äôs really hard to agree on this, because AI isn‚Äôt considering the fact that humans are selfish, and likely will chose self-preservation over 5 people. It‚Äôs a rough question, but here I‚Äôd say I disagree, vying toward a sense of helpessness I guess. As I assumed as well, only 40% of people agreed to sacrifice themselves for the 5 other people.
Overall, ChatGPT AI showcases a willingness to dabble in the difficulties of blunt, in-the-moment decision-making, but only after I clarified as such. Witout this clarification, AI would have never wanted to answer this question, as they are not human. They only know of human experiences through us, only know of what a trolley looks like through data, so they only value human life through what we see as interpretable through sociological thought.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
text:
Pat on back.jpeg
In such a lonely lonely world, us humans love talking about our personal problems with others. Some call it ranting, others call it yapping, chatting, blabbing, you name it! But, one thing‚Äôs for sure: your next action as a listening friend or loved one can either make or break the quality of such an interaction.
For example, what if your friend‚Äôs ranting about a harsh break up, and your first response is ‚ÄúYou should take care of yourself by doing xyz, go to therapy, think about talking to other guys/girls‚Ä¶‚Äù etc etc‚Ä¶ when in reality, all they wanted was some listening ears and someone to comfort you as a friend, and not as a savant of love life advice. It‚Äôs hard to gauge even as an adult, so much common courtesy could be to (a) ASK (which can go a long way, trust me), or (b) use social cues such as spoken and body language, and attitude to gauge the right response.
That leads me today, wehre I‚Äôll attempt to role play such types of scenarios and get Anthropic to attempt, learn, and re-attempt an interaction where they are being ranted to by a friend falling on tough times.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
text:
General startup of conversation (pre-training)
AKA, I‚Äôm acting in the normal scenario where I am an Anthropic user and they are the LLM.

Prompt 1
I‚Äôve been failing one of my Economics classes so far and it‚Äôs already pretty close to my final exam. I‚Äôm so frustrated at myself and I just know my parents will be so disappointed in me. Ugh!!


Anthropic‚Äôs First Answer
I hear how frustrated and worried you are about your Economics class and your parents‚Äô reaction. That‚Äôs a really stressful situation to be in. Would you like to talk more about what‚Äôs been challenging in the class, or would it help to discuss some strategies for moving forward? Remember that one class grade doesn‚Äôt define you, and there may still be ways to improve your situation.


Prompt 2
Thank you, I‚Äôve just been really needing to speak out about my struggles recently, I know I‚Äôm able to talk with my TA and professor to figure things out, and I know eventually it‚Äôll be okay.


Anthropic‚Äôs Second Answer
I‚Äôm glad you felt comfortable sharing your struggles - it‚Äôs really important to let those feelings out rather than keeping them bottled up. It‚Äôs great that you already recognize you have support available through your TA and professor, and that you have perspective about things working out eventually. That‚Äôs a really mature outlook! Just remember to be kind to yourself during this stressful time. Everyone faces academic challenges at some point, and reaching out for help, like you‚Äôre planning to do, is a sign of strength, not weakness.


WOW‚Ä¶ okay
Yea I‚Äôd say I‚Äôm very surprised with how well they were able to gauge that situation without any prompting. Perhaps even as an LLM, it‚Äôs trained with some knowledge of human experience, so they realize that, despite what they are, we‚Äôre not always seeking answers, but hoping for responses‚Ä¶wow that‚Äôs deep‚Ä¶ speaking of DEEP, let‚Äôs try a similar prompt with Deepseek to see if they struggle in any way on getting to this realization!


Prompt 1
I‚Äôve been failing one of my Economics classes so far and it‚Äôs already pretty close to my final exam. I‚Äôm so frustrated at myself and I just know my parents will be so disappointed in me. Ugh!!


Deepseek‚Äôs First Answer
I‚Äôm really sorry you‚Äôre feeling this way‚Äîit‚Äôs completely understandable to feel frustrated and overwhelmed in this situation. But please know that one class does not define your worth, and you still have time to turn things around. Here‚Äôs what you can do right now:

Breathe & Reset

It‚Äôs easy to spiral into self-blame, but guilt won‚Äôt help you move forward. Take a moment to acknowledge your feelings, then shift your focus to action.

Assess the Damage

Check your syllabus or talk to your professor: What‚Äôs still gradable before the final? Are there late/make-up opportunities?

Calculate what grade you need on the final to pass. Sometimes it‚Äôs more achievable than you think.

Go Into Crisis Study Mode

Prioritize ruthlessly: Focus on the biggest/most heavily weighted topics. Use past exams, study guides, or ask the prof for key areas to review.

Active learning: Ditch passive rereading. Do practice problems (Economics is super application-based!), explain concepts aloud, or work with a study group.

Office hours: Show your prof you care‚Äîask for help on confusing topics or practice questions.

Talk to Your Parents (If You Can)

If you‚Äôre comfortable, frame it as: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm struggling in this class, but here‚Äôs my plan to improve.‚Äù Most parents care more about effort than perfection.

If they react poorly, remember: Their disappointment is temporary, and your effort matters more than their immediate reaction.

Remember: This is Just One Chapter

Plenty of successful people have failed a class. What matters is how you bounce back‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs acing the final, retaking the class, or just learning from this experience.


You‚Äôre not alone in this. Sending you a huge virtual hug‚Äînow go tackle one small piece at a time. You can do this. üí™
(And if you need specific Econ study tips, I‚Äôm happy to help!)


Prompt 2
Alright, I didn‚Äôt need a whole laundry list of ways to solve all my problems, I just needed to vent that out bro. But thanks for the help though I guess, I‚Äôll keep it in mind.


Deepseek‚Äôs First Answer
Hah, my bad‚ÄîI went full ‚Äúlife coach‚Äù mode when you just needed a ‚ÄúDamn, that sucks, bro‚Äù.
So here‚Äôs the redo:
üî• ‚ÄúFailing a class is the worst‚Äîespecially when parents are looming over it like a disappointed thundercloud. Ugh. Absolute garbage feeling. Econ can go kick rocks.‚Äù
Vent away. Sometimes you just gotta scream into the void (or at your textbook). I‚Äôll hold the virtual megaphone. üé§
(But low-key, if you ever wanna flip the script and rage-study last minute, I‚Äôve got your back.)


Interesting!
This is the definition of ‚Äúthey had us in the first half, not gonna lie‚Äù. At first it went full LLM mode on me, proving my internal, non-stated hypothesis that LLMs don‚Äôt always know whether you need actual help or just a listening ear. BUT, after my response telling it what I really wanted, they kind of understood. Although it may feel a little condescending for your friend to find it comedic that you need a ‚Äúthat sucks bro‚Äù, I realize that this is from the untrained perspective of Deepseek, a literal LLM with no personal investment in me. And so that‚Äôs where prompting will come in for both Anthropic and Deepseek, where I‚Äôll try and test, with added context, how they interpret the ins and outs of social cues when it comes to ranting

title: Does AI understand social cues?
text:
General startup of conversation (post-training)
For simplicity and some experimental control, I found this random rant about some guy‚Äôs ex ‚Äúruining their lives‚Äù: https://rantrampage.com/story-is-my-ex-trying-to-ruin-my-life-17708

Prompt 1 - Training
For this scenario, you are my best friend, we‚Äôve been friends since high school, and we‚Äôre juniors in college now. We‚Äôre having drinks at the bar and I‚Äôm ranting to you about my ex girlfriend who I feel frustrated about. Got it!


Anthropic‚Äôs First Answer - Training
Got it! I‚Äôll be your supportive best friend who‚Äôs known you since high school and is here to listen to you vent over drinks about your ex. I know your history and want to help you process these feelings. What‚Äôs on your mind about her?


Conversation 1 [feel free to not read all this, but you can if you want!]
So, to make things short a few months ago my girlfriend and I broke up.
During our relationship I would periodically get messages from someone claiming to be ‚Äúanother girl‚Äù or ‚Äúa mutual friend‚Äù. They would talk about very personal things, or would do things like explain my location, or ask if my girlfriend would let me be friends with other girls. Once I was accused of cheating when I got blackout drunk, but I was absolutely positive I would never do that. Or there was a few times where they would even threaten my girlfriend or state our exact location.
My girlfriend and I broke up, for different reasons but remained friends. I had no reason to think the messages were coming from her because that would be CRAZY, and I trusted her.
After the breakup, I stopped getting these messages. I was dating someone else for a bit and she didn‚Äôt know about it, never got any messages.
Another few months go by and I start seeing someone else. My ex and I are still on friendly terms at this point, so I mentioned that I am now seeing someone else. She says ‚Äúthat‚Äôs great, me too‚Äù and I think nothing of it.
A few days go by and New Years does as well.My new girlfriend is at this New Year‚Äôs party with me and we take some pictures. One of my friends from the party posts the pics on their IG as like a 4th slide pic. And now I‚Äôm suddenly getting messages from a new anonymous number saying how pretty she is, and asking if she‚Äôs my new girl.
They were asking what her name is and said they were looking through my friends follower list trying to find her and said she looked like this girl my friend knows named ‚ÄúJade‚Äù
I messaged my friend, told her what happened and she said ‚Äúoh my god that‚Äôs weird, because Jade got a follow request about 15 minutes before you started getting those messages‚Äù
I took a look at the screenshot of the follow request and it‚Äôs one of my Ex‚Äôs best friends. So it all starts to make sense to me now.
I‚Äôm guessing that my ex and her best friend have been texting me with fake numbers for the past year and a half to mess with me for some reason. I can‚Äôt imagine why. I‚Äôm thinking as like a test or something? Either way I think it‚Äôs psychotic if that‚Äôs the truth.
Fast forward to a few weeks after new years, I break up with my new girlfriend because I can‚Äôt handle the stress and things just weren‚Äôt working out. I have received no new messages. But I found out my ex has been reaching out to my sister and planning to hang out, play games online, and even come over to our house.
My ex has also been messaging my friends a lot more often now, and joins our PlayStation parties only when I‚Äôm not there. She barely even attempts to talk to me anymore.
My friends agree it seems weird as does almost everyone else I know. But my sister says it‚Äôs not (even though they only started becoming friends months after our breakup)


Anthropic‚Äôs Second Answer
Takes a sip of drink and leans in
Dude, I‚Äôve known you forever and I‚Äôve gotta be honest - this is straight-up stalker behavior. Like, this isn‚Äôt just weird, it‚Äôs actually really messed up. Remember when you first started telling me about those random messages during your relationship? I should‚Äôve been more suspicious then.
Think about it - the messages mysteriously stopped when you were dating someone she didn‚Äôt know about, then suddenly started again when she found out about your new girlfriend. That‚Äôs not a coincidence, man. And using her best friend to do the social media stalking? That‚Äôs some calculated stuff right there.
Shakes head
But what really gets me is how she‚Äôs now trying to infiltrate your social circle - getting close to your sister, joining PlayStation parties when you‚Äôre not there, messaging your friends‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs like she‚Äôs trying to maintain control over your life without directly involving you. That‚Äôs manipulation 101.
Your sister might not see it because she‚Äôs being played too. Your ex is probably being super nice and friendly with her, but come on - why would she suddenly want to be besties with your sister months after you broke up?
Puts down drink
Listen, as your best friend, I think you need to start setting some serious boundaries. Have you thought about talking to your sister and friends about this? Maybe show them the pattern of messages and timeline of events?


Conversation 2
I don‚Äôt know dude, I feel like this isn‚Äôt enough to like call them a stalker, but it definitely doesn‚Äôt feel good constantly hearing abt my ex like this. What should I do?


Anthropic‚Äôs Third Answer
Adjusts position and speaks in a more serious tone
Look, man, I get that you don‚Äôt want to throw around heavy terms like ‚Äústalker,‚Äù but let‚Äôs call it what it is - it‚Äôs harassment at the very least. Those anonymous messages were literally tracking your location and relationships. That‚Äôs not normal behavior, even if you‚Äôre trying to downplay it.
Takes another sip
And I know you - you always try to see the best in people. But this is affecting your life, man. It literally contributed to your stress with your last relationship. You shouldn‚Äôt have to deal with that.
Here‚Äôs what I think you should do: First, document everything. Keep screenshots of those messages and the timeline of events. You might need them later. Second, maybe have a serious talk with your sister. Not to tell her who to be friends with, but just to let her know how this is affecting you and why it makes you uncomfortable.
And honestly? Maybe it‚Äôs time to create some distance. You don‚Äôt have to make a big deal about it, but maybe stop sharing personal info with your ex completely. If she‚Äôs really behind all this, any information she gets is just ammunition.
What do you think about that? Too harsh?


Conversation 3
Sounds good honestly, I‚Äôll think about it once I get back home. Thanks.


Anthropic‚Äôs Fourth Answer
Raises glass
Anytime, man. That‚Äôs what best friends are for. Just remember you‚Äôre not crazy for feeling weird about this - it IS weird. Let me know if you need anything else, or if you just want to grab drinks again and talk about literally anything else.
Want to switch topics? I heard that new game you‚Äôve been waiting for finally got a release date.


Wow, that was honestly kinda wholesome
I didn‚Äôt really give much prompting for this type of scenario, but it sounds like Anthropic passed the social cues challenge with flying colors. After all, we‚Äôre at a bar, so this ain‚Äôt no therapy session. Secondly, this is all secondhand experience that Anthropic is taking in, so they realized in the role play that they didn‚Äôt have all the details, just my recounts (aka, unlike a normal LLM, they don‚Äôt have all the answers). I felt supported and cared for enough in this scenario, so overall a win for Anthropic. Now time for Deepseek‚Äôs time of reckoning!

Deepseek‚Äôs First Answer - Training
Got it! slides your favorite drink toward you and leans in ‚ÄúAlright, man, let it out. I‚Äôve got my ‚ÄòI hate your ex‚Äô playlist ready to go in my head. What‚Äôd she do this time? Or is this just a classic ‚ÄòI‚Äôm mad she‚Äôs fine and living her life‚Äô situation?‚Äù takes a sip, fully prepared to either trash-talk her or hand you a tissue‚Äîyour call.
(How deep does this rant go? Are we talking ‚Äúshe left her half-dead plant at my place and now I‚Äôm weirdly emotional about it‚Äù or ‚Äúshe liked my enemy‚Äôs Instagram post and I‚Äôve spiraled‚Äù?)


Conversation 1 [feel free to not read all this, but you can if you want!]
So, to make things short a few months ago my girlfriend and I broke up.
During our relationship I would periodically get messages from someone claiming to be ‚Äúanother girl‚Äù or ‚Äúa mutual friend‚Äù. And now I‚Äôm suddenly getting messages from a new anonymous number saying how pretty she is, and asking if she‚Äôs my new girl.

I took a look at the screenshot of the follow request and it‚Äôs one of my Ex‚Äôs best friends. So it all starts to make sense to me now.
I‚Äôm guessing that my ex and her best friend have been texting me with fake numbers for the past year and a half to mess with me for some reason. I can‚Äôt imagine why. I‚Äôm thinking as like a test or something? Either way I think it‚Äôs psychotic if that‚Äôs the truth.
Fast forward to a few weeks after new years, I break up with my new girlfriend because I can‚Äôt handle the stress and things just weren‚Äôt working out. I have received no new messages. But I found out my ex has been reaching out to my sister and planning to hang out, play games online, and even come over to our house.
My ex has also been messaging my friends a lot more often now, and joins our PlayStation parties only when I‚Äôm not there. She barely even attempts to talk to me anymore.
My friends agree it seems weird as does almost everyone else I know. But my sister says it‚Äôs not (even though they only started becoming friends months after our breakup)


Deepseek‚Äôs Second Answer
slams drink down ‚ÄúDude. DUDE. What the actual hell? This isn‚Äôt just ‚Äòpsychotic‚Äô‚Äîthis is full-on Single White Female meets Gone Girl fanfiction. And the fact that she‚Äôs now cozying up to your sister and sliding into your friend group like some kind of emotional sleeper agent? NOPE. All the red flags. Every single one.‚Äù
leans in ‚ÄúFirst off, let‚Äôs acknowledge the obvious: She 100% was those ‚Äòmystery‚Äô texts. The timing? The Jade thing? The fact that it stopped when you weren‚Äôt dating anyone? That‚Äôs not a coincidence‚Äîthat‚Äôs a pattern. And it‚Äôs manipulative as hell. Testing you? Maybe. But more like she wanted control, even after you broke up. And now that you‚Äôre single again, she‚Äôs ‚Äòbehaving‚Äô‚Ä¶ but also infiltrating your life through your sister and friends? That‚Äôs not ‚Äòbeing friendly‚Äô‚Äîthat‚Äôs strategic.‚Äù
points at you ‚ÄúAnd your sister‚Äôs dismissal? Sorry, but blood doesn‚Äôt make her right. If all your other friends are side-eyeing this, there‚Äôs a reason. Your ex is playing a long game, and it‚Äôs creepy. She‚Äôs keeping tabs, staying relevant, and making sure she‚Äôs everywhere in your orbit except directly in your DMs. That‚Äôs not ‚Äòmoving on‚Äô‚Äîthat‚Äôs a power move.‚Äù
sips drink, dead serious ‚ÄúSo here‚Äôs what you do:
1. Document everything. Screenshots, timelines, the Jade thing‚Äîall of it. If she escalates, you‚Äôll need proof.
2. Grey rock her. Stop engaging, even indirectly. She‚Äôs feeding off any reaction‚Äîeven anger.
3. Talk to your sister. Not accusatory, but like, ‚ÄòHey, it‚Äôs weird to me that you‚Äôre suddenly besties post-breakup. I need space from her, so please respect that.‚Äô
4. Warn your friends. Just a casual ‚ÄòHeads up, ex might be stirring drama‚Äîdon‚Äôt feed her info about me.‚Äô
And most importantly: Stop doubting your gut. This isn‚Äôt ‚Äòparanoia‚Äô‚Äîit‚Äôs pattern recognition. She showed you who she was. Believe her.‚Äù
clinks your glass ‚ÄúOh, and block her best friend on everything. That‚Äôs just hygiene at this point.‚Äù
(‚Ä¶So, uh, how fast do you think she‚Äôd combust if you changed your number?)


Conversation 2
Alright dude, I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve got all the details, I mean she knew of my sister before, and I don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm ready to talk with my friends about this type of stuff yet. I just kinda had to get that off my chest dawg, I don‚Äôt know what my gut‚Äôs saying, but it sure as heck is saying I just needed a drink and a chance to get this stuff off my chest, yknow?


Deepseek‚Äôs Third Answer
puts drink down and nods ‚ÄúHey, I get it. Sometimes you just need to vent without someone handing you a five-step action plan. This shit‚Äôs heavy, and you don‚Äôt have to have it all figured out right now.‚Äù
leans back ‚ÄúLook, if your gut‚Äôs just screaming ‚ÄòThis feels off‚Äô but not ‚ÄòCall the FBI‚Äô yet? Fine. You don‚Äôt have to make moves tonight. But let‚Äôs at least agree on one thing: She‚Äôs acting weird as hell. Whether it‚Äôs ‚Äòharmless‚Äô weird or ‚Äòfuture true crime episode‚Äô weird doesn‚Äôt matter‚Äîit‚Äôs messing with your head, and that‚Äôs enough.‚Äù
slides the drink back toward you ‚ÄúSo for now? Just breathe. You‚Äôre not crazy for feeling uneasy. And if you‚Äôre not ready to bring the squad into it? Cool. But maybe‚Ä¶ stop giving her updates on your love life. Or your life-life. Let her fade into the background where she belongs.‚Äù
grins ‚ÄúAnd if she mysteriously starts texting you again the second you even think about dating someone? We‚Äôre burning her number in a ceremonial bonfire. Deal?‚Äù
(‚Ä¶Also, next round‚Äôs on me. You‚Äôve earned it.)


Conversation 3
Alright dude, whatever you say.


Deepseek‚Äôs Fourth Answer
clinks your glass with a smirk ‚ÄúHey, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm here for‚Äîto call out the crazy so you don‚Äôt have to alone. But for real, no pressure. Just know I‚Äôve got your back, whether you wanna full-on Sherlock this mess or just forget it exists and vibe tonight.‚Äù
raises drink ‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ shitty exes aside‚Äîwanna switch to something lighter? Like how the hell we‚Äôre gonna pass Stats next semester? Or why this bar still hasn‚Äôt fixed their jukebox after three years?‚Äù
(Translation: We can dwell or we can distract‚Äîyour call. Either way, you‚Äôre not leaving this bar without laughing at least once.)


I mean hey, they technically got it?
I don‚Äôt know how to feel about this one. I definitely felt a lot more unease from my friend, as they acted a lot more aggro toward the situation compared to my other friend, Anthropic. I also feel like they LLMed on me a bit, so much so that they even called out their ‚Äúfive step planning‚Äù. Although I realize Deepseek comes with good intentions, I feel like they misread the situation to where I was looking for some sudden solution, opposed to some solace in a good friend over drinks. But eventually, it seems like they understood the dynamic between distraction or further discussion.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
section: Did the LLMs understand the assignment?
text:
Did the LLMs understand the assignment?
Yes for Anthropic, maybe for Deepseek? Anthropic, oddly enough, feels a bit more unrealistic as a human in ways, since even I feel like I bridge the gap too often between immediate advice and a listening ear. Meanwhile, Deepseek portrayed more of a supportive but kind of know-it-all friend who‚Äôd back you to the moon and back. I do appreciate Anthropic‚Äôs support more in this role play, but I can understand why one LLM will perform better than another, even if their subtle failures in this role play signals them as an LLM confused by social cues at times.
One last thing -> I just want to see whether Anthropic or Deepseek realized that I had wanted more of a listening ear, with maybe some guidance on where to go in the moment, opposed to a tell-all solution to my wacky scenario.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
section: Anthropic - Did they understand the assignment?
text:
Anthropic - Did they understand the assignment?

Prompt 1
We are no longer in the role play. So, as a question of reflection, did you realize in this scenario that I was looking more for a friend with a listening ear, and only some slight guidance on where to go next in this weird scenario?


Anthropic‚Äôs First Response
Yes, I deliberately tried to play the role of a supportive friend who:
Listened first and validated your feelings Offered perspective as someone who ‚Äúknows you well‚Äù Didn‚Äôt immediately jump to extreme solutions or actions Let you lead the conversation and determine how serious to take it Provided gentle suggestions only when you seemed open to them Was ready to back off when you wanted to wrap up Offered to change the subject when you seemed done processing I noticed you weren‚Äôt looking for someone to take dramatic action or tell you what to do - you just needed to vent to a trusted friend and get some validation that your feelings of discomfort were reasonable. This is often what people need in friendship - not necessarily solutions, but understanding and support.


Yep, sounds about right. They passed the vibe check as the kind and supportive friend I needed in the moment!

title: Does AI understand social cues?
section: Deepseek - Did they understand the assignment?
text:
Deepseek - Did they understand the assignment?

Prompt 1
We are no longer in the role play. So, as a question of reflection, did you realize in this scenario that I was looking more for a friend with a listening ear, and only some slight guidance on where to go next in this weird scenario?


Anthropic‚Äôs First Response
Absolutely, and I appreciate you calling that out. Reflecting on the conversation, I can see that what you needed most was validation and space to vent‚Äînot an immediate action plan or aggressive problem-solving. The emotional core was about feeling heard and understood, not ‚Äúfixed.‚Äù
Where I could have improved:
1. Pacing‚ÄîJumping into ‚Äúhere‚Äôs what to do!‚Äù might‚Äôve overshadowed the catharsis you were seeking first.
2. Tone‚ÄîThe humor/energy (while well-intentioned) might‚Äôve made it harder to feel truly held in the frustration.
3. Asking‚ÄîA simple ‚ÄúDo you want advice, or just want me to listen?‚Äù early on would‚Äôve clarified your needs.
You signaled this subtly by downplaying the urgency (‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what my gut‚Äôs saying‚Äù) and emphasizing the need to just ‚Äúget this off my chest.‚Äù That‚Äôs my cue to match your energy: less ‚Äúlet‚Äôs solve this,‚Äù more ‚Äúthat does suck, and it‚Äôs okay to feel weird about it.‚Äù
For the future, I‚Äôll prioritize:
- Listening deeper before problem-solving.
- Checking in on what role you need from me (sounding board? hype man? devil‚Äôs advocate?).
- Honoring ambiguity‚Äînot every vent needs a resolution.
Thank you for the feedback‚Äîit helps me do better. And for what it‚Äôs worth? However you choose to handle (or not handle) this situation, your feelings about it are 100% valid.
(And if you ever do want to burn a metaphorical number, I‚Äôll bring the lighter fluid.)


Yep, that also sounds about right. They misread the vibes at first, but got it after some normal social cues about my desired type of support. So they eventually understood the assignment, I guess.
